question: Tell me about the course Generative AI
answer: This Degree Level course provides an in-depth exploration of deep generative models, including their probabilistic foundations and learning algorithms. Students will learn about various types of deep generative models such as variational autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, autoregressive models, Diffusion Models and Large Language Models. The course will cover both theoretical foundations and practical implementations of these models using popular frameworks like PyTorch. Students will gain hands-on experience through lectures and assignments, allowing them to explore deep generative models across various AI tasks [5].

question: Tell me about the course Statistical Computing

question: Tell me about the course Algorithms for Data Science (ADS)
answer: The aim of this second-level graduate course is to provide a broad overview and develop the tools and methods necessary for the large-scale problems that naturally arise in many data science-related application areas [11].

Mahoney (2010) Randomized Algorithms for Matrix and Data, Foundations and Trends in Machine Learning, pages 123-224 [12].

question: Who is the instructor for Algorithms for Data Science (ADS)?
answer: The instructor for the Algorithms for Data Science (ADS) course is Arun Rajkumar, Assistant Professor, Department of Data Science and AI, IIT Madras [12].

question: What is the professional background of Arun Rajkumar?
answer: Arun Rajkumar is currently an Assistant Professor at the Data Science and AI department of IIT Madras. Prior to joining IIT Madras, he was a research scientist at the Xerox Research Center (now Conduent Labs), Bangalore for three years. He earned his Ph.D from the Indian Institute of Science where he worked on 'Ranking from Pairwise Comparisons'. His research interests are in the areas of Machine learning, statistical learning theory with applications to education and healthcare [12-14].

question: Tell me about the course Business Data Management (Diploma Level)
answer: This Diploma Level course provides a basic understanding of how businesses are organised and run from a data perspective. A significant source of data sets and problems for data scientists will come from the business domain [24].

question: What is the Course ID for Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The Course ID for Business Data Management (Diploma Level) is BSMS2001 [24].

question: What is the course structure and assessments for Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The Business Data Management course has 12 weeks of coursework, weekly online assignments, 2 in-person invigilated quizzes, and 1 in-person invigilated end term exam [25]. For details of standard course structure and assessments, students can visit the Academics page [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 1 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 1 of Business Data Management are Consumption and demand: Micro & Macro economics: the role of data, production, consumption and exchange, consumption baskets, sources of consumer survey data [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 2 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 2 of Business Data Management are Micro-economic concepts: Utility: cardinal vs ordinal, indifference curves. Demand and supply curves, changes in demand and elasticity. production cost, cost curves. Make vs buy decisions, production quantity decisions [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 3 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 3 of Business Data Management are Firm level strategies and performance data: Objectives and types of pricing strategies, analysis of firm performance - key ratios. Analysis examples: Ultratech, Page Industries, Nestle, TCS [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 4 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 4 of Business Data Management are Analysing industry level data: Industry definition and classification codes, IIP and PMI, industry market structure and concentration indices, competitive positioning in an industry - Porter's five forces. Analysis examples: Cement industry, Textile industry, FMCG industry, IT industry [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 5 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 5 of Business Data Management are Case study 1 - Fabmart (E-Commerce): Introduction to E-Commerce, Fabmart case introduction, explanation of data set & questions to be answered, revenue pareto, volume pareto, scatter plot of sales and revenue, revenue trend [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 6 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 6 of Business Data Management are Fabmart case continued: Sales analysis, organisation of distribution centre, analysis of sales trends, average days of inventory, ledger, avoiding stockouts [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 7 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 7 of Business Data Management are Case study 2 - Ace Gears (Manufacturing): Introduction to the manufacturing sector, context of the automotive industry during the years 2019-2021, explanation of data set containing monthly information on sales, production, inventory and costing. Revenue trend analysis, portfolio management [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 8 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 8 of Business Data Management are Ace Gears case study continued: Regional sales analysis, sales agent planning, production scheduling, scrap analysis, unit level profitability analysis, raw material re-ordering and safety stock [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 9 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 9 of Business Data Management are Case study 3 - Tech Enterprises (IT): Introduction to HR as a function, Introduction to the Tech Enterprises, internal sourcing, ranking of internal candidates, job description, sourcing channels and their analysis, recruitment process and onboarding [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 10 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 10 of Business Data Management are Case study 4 - PayBuddy (Fin Tech): Introduction to Finance Industry and Fintech, payment processing and money flow, new credit product introduction, nudge economics, payment transaction and customer data set, identifying rules to target the appropriate customers [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 11 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 11 of Business Data Management are Paybuddy case continued: Introduction to A/B testing, analysis of the A/B testing data, credit risk evaluation, risk-return tradeoffs [25].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 12 of Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 12 of Business Data Management are Discussion on student acquired data sets. Wrap upaWrap up (summary) of the case studies, course project work [25].

question: Who are the instructors for Business Data Management (Diploma Level)?
answer: The instructors for the Business Data Management course are Dr. G Venkatesh, Prof. Suresh Babu, and Dr. Milind Gandhe [24].

question: What are the research interests of Dr. Milind Gandhe?
answer: Dr. Milind Gandhe's primary research interests are AI (Natural Language Processing, Mathematical Logic, Hardware acceleration for AI at the Edge) and Interaction between Society and Technology [26].

question: Who is the instructor for Statistics for Data Science II (Foundational Level)?

question: What is the professional background of Andrew Thangaraj?
answer: Andrew Thangaraj received his B. Tech in Electrical Engineering from IIT Madras in 1998 and Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta, USA in 2003. He was a post-doctoral researcher at the GTL-CNRS Telecom lab at Georgia Tech Lorraine, Metz, France from Aug 2003 till May 2004. Since 2004, he has been a faculty at the Department of Electrical Engineering, IIT Madras, where he is currently a professor. His research interests are in the broad areas of information theory, error-control coding and information-theoretic aspects of cryptography [30]. He has also served as an Editor for the IEEE Transactions on Communications and is currently an Associate Editor for the IEEE Transactions on Information Theory [30]. He is also one of the NPTEL coordinators for IIT Madras and a National MOOCs coordinator for NPTEL under the SWAYAM project of the MHRD. Prof. Andrew is also one of the coordinators for the IIT Madras Online BSc Degree Program [31].

question: Tell me about Prof. Nitin Chandrachoodan's background.
answer: Prof. Nitin Chandrachoodan received his BTech (electronics and communication engineering) from IIT Madras in 1996, and PhD from the University of Maryland at College Park in 2002, in the area of high-level synthesis techniques for mapping DSP algorithms to architectures. He has been with the department of electrical engineering at IIT Madras since 2004, where he is currently a professor [34]. question: What is the professional background of Dr. Karthik Raman?
answer: Dr. Karthik Raman is an Assistant Professor at the Department of Biotechnology, Indian Institute of Technology Madras since April 2011. His research interests are in the areas of metabolic network analysis, with applications in metabolic engineering and drug target identification. He received his Ph.D. in 2009 from the lab of Prof. Nagasuma Chandra at the Supercomputer Education and Research Centre at the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore. Following his Ph.D., Karthik was a post-doctoral researcher at the lab of Prof. Dr. Andreas Wagner, at the University of Zürich, Switzerland. Karthik’s post-doctoral research was involved the analysis of signalling circuits in yeast as well as synthetic logic circuits, for their robustness and evolvability [41].

question: Tell me about the background of Harish Guruprasad Ramaswamy.
answer: Harish Guruprasad Ramaswamy is currently an assistant professor at the computer science and engineering (CSE) department of IIT Madras. His primary areas of interest are in machine learning, statistical learning theory and optimisation. He was previously a research scientist at IBM research labs and a post-doc at University of Michigan. He completed his PhD at the Computer Science and Automation (CSA) department of the Indian Institute of Science (IISc), Bangalore advised by Prof. Shivani Agarwal. He has been fortunate to work with Profs. Ambuj Tewari and Clayton Scott during his PhD and postdoc [43]. He received his Masters and Ph.D degrees in Computer Science and Automation from Indian Institute of Science, in 2008 and 2013, respectively. He was awarded the third prize for his Ph.D. dissertation, by the IEEE Intelligent Transportation Systems Society (ITSS). He is the coauthor of a book entitled `Stochastic Recursive Algorithms for Optimization: Simultaneous Perturbation Methods', published by Springer in 2013. His research interests are in reinforcement learning, simulation optimization and multi-armed bandits, with applications in transportation systems, wireless networks and recommendation systems [44].

question: Tell me about the course Introduction to Natural Language Processing (i-NLP) (Degree Level)
answer: This Degree Level course aims to provide knowledge and understanding of linguistics techniques, classical (statistical) approaches, and deep learning approaches (RNN and CNN) to NLP. It also covers Attention Mechanism, Transformers, and Large Language Models (LLMs). The course aims to enable participants to read and understand latest NLP research papers, identify applicable NLP techniques, implement NLP models, and develop applications based on textual generative models [50].

question: What is the professional background of Prof. S. Umesh?
answer: S. Umesh is a Professor of Electrical Engineering at IIT-Madras. He completed his PhD from the University of Rhode Island, USA and his PostDoctoral Fellowship from the City University of New York. He has also been a visiting researcher at AT&T Research Laboratories, USA; at Machine Intelligence Laboratory Cambridge University Engineering Department, UK; and the Department of Computer Science, RWTH-Aachen, Germany [23]. question: What is the course structure and assessments for Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The Statistics for Data Science I course has 12 weeks of coursework, weekly online assignments, 2 in-person invigilated quizzes, and 1 in-person invigilated end term exam [66]. For details of standard course structure and assessments, students can visit the Academics page [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 1 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 1 of Statistics for Data Science I are Introduction and type of data, Types of data, Descriptive and Inferential statistics, Scales of measurement [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 2 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 2 of Statistics for Data Science I are Describing categorical data Frequency distribution of categorical data, Best practices for graphing categorical data, Mode and median for categorical variable [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 3 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 3 of Statistics for Data Science I are Describing numerical data Frequency tables for numerical data, Measures of central tendency - Mean, median and mode, Quartiles and percentiles, Measures of dispersion - Range, variance, standard deviation and IQR, Five number summary [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 4 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 4 of Statistics for Data Science I are Association between two variables - Association between two categorical variables - Using relative frequencies in contingency tables, Association between two numerical variables - Scatterplot, covariance, Pearson correlation coefficient, Point bi-serial correlation coefficient [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 5 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 5 of Statistics for Data Science I are Basic principles of counting and factorial concepts - Addition rule of counting, Multiplication rule of counting, Factorials [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 6 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 6 of Statistics for Data Science I are Permutations and combinations [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 7 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 7 of Statistics for Data Science I are Probability Basic definitions of probability, Events, Properties of probability [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 8 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 8 of Statistics for Data Science I are Conditional probability - Multiplication rule, Independence, Law of total probability, Bayes’ theorem [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 9 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 9 of Statistics for Data Science I are Random Variables - Random experiment, sample space and random variable, Discrete and continuous random variable, Probability mass function, Cumulative density function [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 10 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 10 of Statistics for Data Science I are Expectation and Variance - Expectation of a discrete random variable, Variance and standard deviation of a discrete random variable [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 11 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 11 of Statistics for Data Science I are Binomial and poisson random variables - Bernoulli trials, Independent and identically distributed random variable, Binomial random variable, Expectation and variance of abinomial random variable, Poisson distribution [66].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 12 of Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 12 of Statistics for Data Science I are Introduction to continous random variables - Area under the curve, Properties of pdf, Uniform distribution, Exponential distribution [66].

question: What are the reference documents for Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The reference documents for Statistics for Data Science I are Descriptive Statistics (VOL 1) and Probability and Probability Distributions (VOL 2) [67].

question: What are the prescribed books for Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The prescribed books for the Statistics for Data Science I course are Introductory Statistics (10th Edition) - ISBN 9780321989178, by Neil A. Weiss published by Pearson and Introductory Statistics (4th Edition) - by Sheldon M. Ross [67].

question: Who is the instructor for Statistics for Data Science I (Foundational Level)?
answer: The instructor for the Statistics for Data Science I course is Usha Mohan, Professor, Department of Management Studies, IIT Madras [67].

question: What is the professional background of Usha Mohan?
answer: Usha Mohan holds a Ph.D. from Indian Statistical Institute. She has worked as a researcher in ISB Hyderabad and Lecturer at University of Hyderabad prior to joining IIT Madras. She offers courses in Data analytics, Operations research, and Supply chain management. Her research interests include developing quantitative models in operations management and combinatorial optimization [67].

question: Tell me about the course Market Research (Degree Level)
answer: This Degree Level course aims to provide a basic understanding of research methodology and its implementation in different business domains, understand the role, scope, process, cost, and value of marketing research, match research techniques to marketing problems, analyse data and translate them into actionable findings, and enable students to do hands-on research to solve business problems [68].

question: Is there an application deadline for Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: Yes, applications for the May 2025 Batch of the Market Research course close on May 20, 2025 [68].

question: When is the exam for Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The exam for the Market Research course is on July 13, 2025 [68].

question: What is the course structure and assessments for Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: For details of standard course structure and assessments for the Market Research course, students can visit the Academics page [69].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 1 of Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 1 of Market Research are Marketing Research, the Research Process and Problem Formulation: The Role of Research in Marketing and the Marketing Research Process, Defining the Marketing Research Problem and Developing an Approach [69].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 2 of Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The topic covered in Week 2 of Market Research is Research Design Formulation: Research Design, Exploratory Research Design, Descriptive Research Design, Causal Research Design and Test Markets [69].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 3 of Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The topic covered in Week 3 of Market Research is Designing Data Collection Methods and Forms: Surveys and Interviews, Measurement, Measurement Scales, Questionnaires, and Instruments [69].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 4 of Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The topic covered in Week 4 of Market Research is Different Market Research Applications, and the Industry Approach to each: Key marketing issues like new product development, STP, branding, etc. and the MR tools and techniques to address each [69].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 5 of Market Research (Degree Level)?
answer: The topic covered in Week 5 of Market Research is Data Analysis and Interpretation: Entering the Data in SPSS, Examining the Data and Univariate Data Analysis: Descriptive Statistics, Cross Tabulation, Graphical Display of Data, Chart Deception and Hypothesis Testing: Mean Differences, ANOVA, Multivariate Data Analysis: An Overview, Exploratory Factor Analysis, Cluster Analysis, Multiple Regression in SPSS [69].

Malhotra and Satyabhusan Dash (Pearson Education, 7th Edition, 2019) and Business Research Methods, A South Asian Perspective by William G. Zikmund, Barry J. Babin, Jon C. Carr, Atanu Adhikari and Mitch Griffin (Cengage Learning, 9th Edition, 2013) [70].

question: What are the reference books for Market Research (Degree Level)?

Field (SAGE, 5th Edition, 2000), and Basic Marketing Research by Gilbert A Churchill (Fort Worth, Dryden Press, 7th Edition, 1999) [70].

question: What is the professional background of Prof. Ponnurangam Kumaraguru?
answer: Prof. Ponnurangam Kumaraguru (

) is a Professor of Computer Science at IIIT-Hyderabad, a Visiting Faculty at IIT Kanpur, an Adjunct faculty at IIIT Delhi, and Associated Researcher at Robert Bosch Centre for Data Science and AI, IIT Madras. question: Tell me about the course Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)
answer: The Advanced Algorithms course covers greedy algorithms, matroids, dynamic programming, maximum flows, applications of flows, NP-hardness, approximation algorithms, randomized algorithms, exact algorithms, parameterized algorithms, kernelization, and practical approaches to coping with hardness [97].

question: What is the course structure and assessments for Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The Advanced Algorithms course has 12 weeks of coursework, weekly online assignments, 2 in-person invigilated quizzes, and 1 in-person invigilated end term exam [97]. For details of standard course structure and assessments, students can visit the Academics page [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 1 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 1 of Advanced Algorithms are Greedy Algorithms: Storing Files on Tape; Scheduling Classes; Stable Matchings [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 2 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 2 of Advanced Algorithms are Matroids: A Generic Optimization Problem, Motivating the Definition, Examples of Matroids, Scheduling with Deadlines [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 3 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 3 of Advanced Algorithms are Dynamic Programming: Longest Increasing Subsequence, Edit Distance, Subset Sum, Optimal BSTs [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 4 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 4 of Advanced Algorithms are Maximum Flows: Flows, Cuts, Maxflow-Mincut, Augmenting Paths, Bipartite Matchings, Other Settings [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 5 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 5 of Advanced Algorithms are Applications of Flows: Exam Scheduling, Baseball Elimination, Project Selection [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 6 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 6 of Advanced Algorithms are NP-hardness: P, NP, NP-hardness, NP-completeness, Reductions and SAT, 3SAT, Maximum Independent Set, Graph Coloring, Subset Sum [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 7 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 7 of Advanced Algorithms are Approximation Algorithms: Introduction to Approximation Frameworks, Vertex Cover via Maximal Matchings, Vertex Cover via LP rounding, TSP, Set Cover [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 8 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 8 of Advanced Algorithms are Randomized Algorithms – Monte Carlo v. Las Vegas, Min-Cut Algorithm, MAX SAT via the Probabilistic Methods, 2SAT via Markov Chains, Primality Testing [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 9 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 9 of Advanced Algorithms are Exact Algorithms – Branch and Bound, An Inclusion-Exclusion approach to Hamiltonian Path, Dynamic Programming for TSP, Local Search [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 10 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 10 of Advanced Algorithms are Parameterized Algorithms – Closest String, Iterative Compression for FVS, Randomized Algorithm for k-Path, DP over subsets - Set Cover [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 11 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 11 of Advanced Algorithms are Kernelization – Vertex Cover, Matrix Rigidity, Feedback Arc Set on Tournaments, Max Sat, Edge Clique Cover [97].

question: What are the topics covered in Week 12 of Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The topics covered in Week 12 of Advanced Algorithms are Practical Approaches to Coping with Hardness – SAT Solvers, SAT reductions, LP solvers, LP reductions [97].

question: What are the prescribed books for Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The prescribed books for the Advanced Algorithms course will be announced in class [97].

question: Who is the instructor for Advanced Algorithms (Degree Level)?
answer: The instructor for the Advanced Algorithms course is Prof. Venkatesh Raman [98].

question: Tell me about the background of Prof. Balaraman Ravindran.
answer: B. Ravindran heads the Robert Bosch Centre for Data Science & Artificial Intelligence (RBCDSAI) at IIT Madras. He is a Professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at IIT Madras. His research interests span geometric deep learning and reinforcement learning. He is one of the founding executive committee members of the India chapter of ACM SIGKDD and serves on the editorial boards of multiple journals. He has published more than 100 papers. He received his PhD from the University of Massachusetts, Amherst and his Master’s degree from the Indian Institute of Science, Bangalore. He is a senior member of AAAI and an ACM Distinguished Member [99].

question: Tell me about the course Machine Learning Practice - Project (Diploma Level)
answer: The purpose of this Diploma Level machine learning project is to apply ML models learnt in ML courses on real-world data and create an effective predictive model. It aims to help students discover patterns, make predictions, answer business questions, detect trends, and solve problems [100].

question: What will students gain from the Machine Learning Practice - Project (Diploma Level)?
answer: After completing the project, students will gain experience in applying different ML techniques on real-world data, proficiency in numpy, panda, and sklearn libraries, and familiarity with the 5 components of an ML project (data, model, cost function, optimization, and evaluation). A viva will be conducted by an industry expert [101].
